title: 111_hr20
content:
The Act is titled the Melanie Blocker Stokes MOTHERS Act and defines postpartum conditions as postpartum depression or postpartum psychosis. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is referred to as the Secretary in this Act. The Act focuses on research on postpartum conditions and aims to expand and intensify related activities. The Secretary is encouraged to continue activities on postpartum conditions, including research on causes, treatments, epidemiological studies, screening techniques, clinical research, and education programs for health care. The Secretary is encouraged to continue activities on postpartum conditions, including research on causes, treatments, and education programs for health care professionals and the public. This may involve a national campaign to increase awareness and knowledge of postpartum conditions through public service announcements and education for new mothers and their families. The curr_chunk discusses information about postpartum conditions, including symptoms, coping methods, and treatment resources. Sense of Congress regarding longitudinal study on mental health consequences for women after resolving a pregnancy. The Director of the National Institute of Mental Health may conduct a longitudinal study on the mental health consequences for women after resolving a pregnancy in various ways. This study will assess the immediate and long-term mental health effects of carrying the pregnancy to term and parenting, placing the child for adoption, miscarriage, and having an abortion. Reports on the findings of the study will be submitted to Congress periodically. TITLE II--DELIVERY OF SERVICES REGARDING POSTPARTUM CONDITIONS

Establishment of grant program for services to individuals with a postpartum condition and their families. The Secretary may grant funds to eligible entities for projects providing essential services to individuals with postpartum conditions and their families. Projects may include outpatient and home-based health services, inpatient care management, and support services for families. The Secretary may grant funds to eligible entities for projects providing essential services to individuals with postpartum conditions and their families, including inpatient care management services, improving healthcare quality and availability, and providing education on postpartum conditions to promote early diagnosis and treatment. The Secretary may grant funds to eligible entities for projects providing essential services to individuals with postpartum conditions and their families, including education on postpartum conditions for new mothers and fathers before leaving the health facility. Integration with other grant programs may be possible, and certain requirements must be met for a grant under this section. The Secretary may grant funds to eligible entities for projects providing essential services to individuals with postpartum conditions and their families. Agreements must be made by the applicant, including limitations on grant usage and charges to individuals receiving services. The applicant must post notices about federal policies regarding charges for services provided under the grant. Additionally, they must submit reports detailing how grant funds were utilized. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to eligible entities seeking a grant under this section to comply with requirements. Definitions include 'eligible entity' as a public or nonprofit private entity, and 'postpartum condition' as postpartum depression or postpartum psychosis. TITLE III--GENERAL PROVISIONS

SEC. 301. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

    To carry out this Act and the amendment made by section 201, there 
are authorized to be appropriated:
            (1) $3,000,000 for fiscal year 2010; and
            (2) necessary sums for fiscal years 2011 and 2012.

SEC. 302. REPORT BY THE SECRETARY.

    The Secretary will conduct a study on screening for postpartum conditions and submit a report to Congress within 2 years.

SEC. 303. LIMITATION. SEC. 303. LIMITATION. The Secretary cannot use funds from this Act for activities already carried out by the Department of Health and Human Services.
